conclusion: The semicircular brick has a radius R, and the laser beam is injected perpendicular to the diameter MN at the center point O.
The laser beam consists of red and green light, and as the beam shifts left from O, only monochromatic light emerges from the curved surface.
The angle between the emitted light and the incident direction is 30 degrees, regardless of reflection.
The curved surface of the semicircular brick is part of a circle with radius R. The normal to the surface at any point is the radius of the circle at that point.
When light exits the curved surface, it undergoes refraction according to Snell's Law: n sin(theta_1) = sin(theta_2).
The problem states that the angle between the emitted light and the incident direction is 30 degrees. This means the angle of refraction theta_2 is related to the geometry of the semicircle.
The laser beam enters the semicircular brick at point O, perpendicular to the diameter MN. As the beam shifts left, it strikes the curved surface at different points.
At any point on the curved surface, the angle of incidence theta_1 depends on the position of the beam inside the semicircle.
The angle between the emitted light and the incident direction is 30 degrees, meaning theta_2 = theta_1 + 30 degrees.
Substituting theta_2 = theta_1 + 30 degrees into Snell's Law: n sin(theta_1) = sin(theta_1 + 30 degrees).
Using the trigonometric identity for sin(theta_1 + 30 degrees): sin(theta_1 + 30 degrees) = sin(theta_1) cos(30 degrees) + cos(theta_1) sin(30 degrees).
Substituting into Snell's Law: n sin(theta_1) = sin(theta_1) cos(30 degrees) + cos(theta_1) sin(30 degrees).
Simplify the equation: n sin(theta_1) - sin(theta_1) cos(30 degrees) = cos(theta_1) sin(30 degrees).
Factor out sin(theta_1): sin(theta_1) (n - cos(30 degrees)) = cos(theta_1) sin(30 degrees).
Divide both sides by cos(theta_1) (assuming cos(theta_1) != 0): tan(theta_1) = sin(30 degrees) / (n - cos(30 degrees)).
Substitute sin(30 degrees) = 1/2 and cos(30 degrees) = sqrt(3)/2: tan(theta_1) = 1/2 / (n - sqrt(3)/2).
